summary: This is an email chain from May-June 2019 between FBI personnel and an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York regarding the management and scanning of documents for the Epstein investigation. The discussion focuses on logistics for transferring files and using an outside vendor to digitize sensitive materials, referencing past cases as examples.

persons.name: Semos, L.
persons.context: FBI sender suggesting to touch base on Monday regarding the Epstein investigation records management.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York
persons.context: Sender from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York providing example cases and discussing vendor process for scanning sensitive Epstein investigation documents.

connections.description: FBI colleagues coordinating to discuss the Epstein investigation records management.

connections.description: Collaborating on logistics for document handling and vendor selection for the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Files received confirmation
events.description: Confirmation that files for the Epstein investigation have been received and appear complete.

events.title: Document management coordination
events.description: Ongoing email coordination between the FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the transfer, scanning, and vendor management of sensitive Epstein investigation documents.
personsInvolved: Assistant U.S. Attorney Southern District of New York

keyFacts: The FBI and the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York were actively coordinating the physical management and digitization of documents related to the Epstein investigation in May-June 2019.
The documents were considered sensitive, and the plan involved using a pre-vetted, confidential outside vendor for scanning, referencing past cases like U.S. v. Ng Lap Seng as precedents.
The email chain indicates logistical discussions about whether documents should be sent directly to the U.S. Attorney's Office or to the FBI's New York field office before scanning.
The correspondence shows inter-agency collaboration and procedural planning for handling evidence in a high-profile investigation.
